latest news.eng_title: US STOCKS-S&P 500, Nasdaq edge higher after services activity data
latest news.summary: The Nasdaq and S&P 500 indexes rose on Thursday after a services activity survey showed a rise in economic activity, and weekly jobless claims declined. The Institute for Supply Management survey showed services sector activity rose to 51.5 in August, above expectations. The number of Americans filing new applications for jobless benefits declined last week, according to a Labor Department report. However, ADP National Employment data showed private employers hired the fewest number of workers in 3-1/2 years in August. Traders' bets for a 25-basis point reduction in interest rates at the Fed's September meeting now stand at 55%. Ross Mayfield, investment strategist at Baird, said, 'The one positive you could take away is that layoffs seem to remain somewhat muted.' The tech-heavy Nasdaq outperformed, led by Nvidia, Amazon.com, and Apple, while Tesla's shares jumped 6% after it said it will launch the full self-driving advanced driver assistance software in the first quarter next year in Europe and China, pending regulatory approval.
latest news.title: US STOCKS-S&P 500, Nasdaq edge higher after services activity data

latest news.eng_title: Tesla's AI Roadmap: Autonomous Driving on Two New Markets in Early 2025
latest news.summary: Tesla's AI team has published its roadmap for the next few months, reaffirming its goal of launching its autonomous driving technology on two new markets in early 2025. The company's Full Self-Driving (FSD) software has been available in the US since October 2020 as a beta feature. Since then, the technology has become increasingly advanced, moving from 'Beta' to 'Supervised' in April. The change, primarily cosmetic, involved removing certain warning terms from Tesla, including a statement warning drivers that FSD 'might do the worst thing at the worst time' and reminding them to 'always keep their hands on the wheel.' Tesla must obtain regulatory approval from local authorities before it can start selling its packages. Elon Musk, CEO of Tesla, visited Beijing earlier this year as a company ready to register its software with the authorities. 'Very soon, we will ask for regulatory approval of Tesla's supervised FSD in Europe, China, and other countries,' Musk said during the company's second-quarter earnings call in July. 'And I think we're likely to get it before the end of the year, which will be an obvious driver of demand in those regions.' Musk wrote on X that right-hand drive markets should 'hopefully' get FSD later in the first quarter of 2025 or early in the second quarter, pending regulatory approval. The CEO made the growing adoption of FSD a key point of Tesla's long-term approach to fully autonomous vehicles and a fleet of autonomous robotaxis. To progress in the development of the software and convince regulators, Tesla must continue to collect data. Since its second quarter, Tesla's clients have driven approximately 1.6 billion miles with FSD activated.
latest news.title: La feuille de route de l'IA de Tesla donne un aperçu de l'avenir de l'entreprise

latest news.eng_title: Tesla Has Already Lost the Robotaxi War
latest news.summary: Tesla has been discussing robotaxis for years, but has yet to launch one on public streets. In contrast, two companies have already launched robotaxis, and even Uber is supporting their efforts. According to Travis Hoium, 'Tesla is falling behind' in the robotaxi market. The Motley Fool's affiliate, Travis Hoium, explains the reasons behind Tesla's delay in a recent video. As of August 30, 2024, Tesla's stock price was $4.13, while Uber's stock price was $0.39.
latest news.title: Tesla Has Already Lost the Robotaxi War

latest news.eng_title: Tesla to Launch Autonomous Driving Software in Europe and China in 2025
latest news.summary: Tesla plans to launch its 'Full Self Driving' autonomous driving software in Europe and China in early 2025, according to a message on the social media platform X. The company, owned by Elon Musk, states that this feature will be available through a paid subscription, pending regulatory approval from European and Chinese traffic authorities. Musk has expressed confidence in obtaining the necessary approvals by the end of 2024. The 'Full Self Driving' system has been a key driver of Tesla's growth in recent years, with the company shifting its focus towards the development of artificial intelligence and autonomous technology. However, it's worth noting that the system is not fully autonomous, as drivers are still required to be present and attentive while operating the vehicle. Musk has promised investors since 2016 that Tesla would offer a fully autonomous driving technology, but regulatory and technical limitations have hindered progress. Following the announcement, Tesla's stock price rose by 2.8% in pre-market trading, surpassing $225 per share. The company has lost 14% of its market capitalization over the past year.
latest news.title: Tesla lanzará su software de asistencia de conducción autónoma en Europa y China a principios de 2025

latest news.eng_title: All About the Happenings With Tesla Today, 9/4/2024 - Including 4680 Battery, Actually Smart Summon, and Optimus
latest news.summary: Tesla's stock surged by 5% today, partly due to a series of green candles in the stock market indicating strong buying interest. The company reported a 17% increase in sales in China for August, up from July, and a modest 3% year-over-year. There's speculation about a potential six-seat variant of the Model Y, which could broaden its appeal in markets with larger families. Elon Musk hinted at a future filled with robotics, suggesting Tesla's work with Optimus might be nearing a significant reveal or advancement. A Tesla engineer shared insights into the company's progress with the 4680 battery cell, promising longer ranges and potentially lower costs. The community on X is abuzz with speculation about what Musk's comments on robotics could mean for Tesla's product line, possibly integrating robotics into their vehicles or standalone products like Optimus. Actually Smart Summon has been seen in action, but there are cases where it seems to glitch, and someone had to restart it, causing their car to move slowly and take up space in a parking lot. However, in most cases, it appears to work flawlessly, saving time and effort from those who are out at the gym, shopping, or anywhere else.
latest news.title: All About the Happenings With Tesla Today, 9/4/2024 - Including 4680 Battery, Actually Smart Summon, and Optimus

latest news.eng_title: Intel announces first round of layoffs. Here's how many Bay Area employees were affected
latest news.summary: Intel has announced the first round of layoffs, affecting 54 workers in the Bay Area, as part of its plan to reduce its global workforce by 15%. The semiconductor giant plans to eliminate 15,000 positions globally before the year's end and suspend dividend payments from the fourth quarter until cash flows improve. Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger said, 'This is an incredibly hard day for Intel as we are making some of the most consequential changes in our company's history.' The layoffs are part of a broader trend, with major tech companies such as Meta, Cisco, Tesla, Google, Broadcom, PayPal, Apple, and Salesforce also announcing significant job cuts since the COVID-19 pandemic. Intel employs 110,000 people worldwide and has previously reduced its workforce by 5% following job cuts announced in October 2022. Gelsinger described the recent decisions as the hardest of his career, saying, 'These decisions have challenged me to my core.'
latest news.title: Intel announces first round of layoffs. Here's how many Bay Area employees were affected

latest news.eng_title: Andreessen Horowitz just dealt a blow to tech's move-to-Miami movement
latest news.summary: Andreessen Horowitz, a prominent venture capital firm, has abandoned its plans to move to Miami, citing a shift to a virtual operating model. This move comes after the firm's cofounders, Ben Horowitz and Marc Andreessen, expressed differing views on remote work. Ben Horowitz initially stated that the firm would have a 'new operating model' with satellite offices in Miami, New York City, and Santa Monica, but now the firm is virtual. Marc Andreessen later said that remote work had 'detonated' how we connect and that it's 'not a good life' for younger workers. This decision is a blow to the 'move-to-Miami' movement, which was popularized by tech figures such as Keith Rabois. According to The Wall Street Journal, Rabois is now planning to live in San Francisco again and has renovated his home in the city. VC investment in Miami also saw a huge decrease in 2023, dropping 70% to $2 billion. Other companies, such as Elon Musk's SpaceX and X, have relocated to Austin, Texas, which has emerged as another popular destination for firms leaving the Valley.
latest news.title: Andreessen Horowitz just dealt a blow to tech's move-to-Miami movement

latest news.eng_title: Is Tesla Stock A Buy Or A Sell As Investors Look To October And The Robotaxi Reveal?
latest news.summary: Tesla's stock has declined 12% this year, but analysts are optimistic about the company's future prospects, particularly with the upcoming robotaxi reveal event on October 10. The event will showcase Tesla's advancements in Full Self-Driving (FSD) and artificial intelligence (AI). Cathie Wood's Ark Invest firm has updated its Tesla stock price target to $2,600 by 2029, citing the company's potential to corner the market on zero-emission vehicle credits. However, Tesla faces challenges, including a decline in vehicle deliveries and a 28% drop in earnings per share expected for 2024. The company has also faced scrutiny from regulators, including a National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) investigation into its Autopilot system. Despite these challenges, Tesla remains a top pick in the U.S. auto space, with Morgan Stanley predicting a 40% upside to the stock. Elon Musk has hinted that he needs more TSLA shares and voting power to make Tesla a leader in AI & robotics, and has been shaking up the company, letting top executives go and announcing layoffs. However, he has also started hiring back employees and is focused on FSD and AI. The European Union has imposed a lower tariff on Tesla vehicles imported from China, and the company is expected to unveil its robotaxi on October 10, which could potentially put it in competition with Uber and Lyft.
latest news.title: Is Tesla Stock A Buy Or A Sell As Investors Look To October And The Robotaxi Reveal?

news knowledge.summary: As of August 20, 2024, tech companies have laid off over 124,000 employees, bringing the total number of layoffs since 2022 to 428,449. Major tech companies such as Microsoft, Alphabet, Apple, Amazon, Tesla, Dell, Intel, IBM, Cisco, SAP, Salesforce, Cohere, Stability AI, TikTok, YouTube, Snap, Match Group, Bumble, PayPal, Swiggy, Unacademy, Byju's, Ola, Koo, Paytm, Twitch, and Discord have all announced layoffs, with some companies cutting up to 50% of their workforce. The layoffs are attributed to a combination of factors, including cost-cutting to invest in AI, a global downturn, over-hiring during the pandemic, and falling behind due to not investing in AI at the right time. 'We need to simplify execution and drive velocity,' said Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai, while Tesla's Elon Musk announced that the company would be cutting'more than 10%' of its global workforce to cut costs. 'We grew too quickly and wanted to sharpen our focus,' said Discord CEO Jason Citron. The layoffs have had a significant impact on employees, with some companies offering voluntary leave programs and re-skilling measures to help those affected.
news knowledge.title: Google

news knowledge.eng_title: These Tech Companies Have Seen The Biggest Layoffs Of 2024 So Far
news knowledge.summary: According to data from Layoffs.fyi, almost 100,000 people in the tech industry have lost their jobs in the first half of 2024. Dell is at the top of the list, with a total of 26,000 employees laid off, which is 20% of its workforce. Intel ranks second, having let go of 15,000 employees in August, while Tesla takes the third spot, having downsized by 10% after laying off 14,500 workers in two separate rounds in April. 'The figures are current to August 15th,' according to the analysis. 'Elon Musk's automotive company Tesla takes the third spot, having downsized by 10 percent after laying off 14,500 workers in two separate rounds in April.'
news knowledge.title: These Tech Companies Have Seen The Biggest Layoffs Of 2024 So Far

news knowledge.eng_title: Ranked: The Biggest Layoffs in Tech So Far in 2024
news knowledge.summary: Tech companies have been cutting jobs in the thousands this year, with Dell and Intel leading the pack. Dell is expected to cut 20,000 jobs this year, after an initial 6,000 in March, as part of an AI pivot. Intel has already cut 15,000 jobs and is struggling with operating losses and lost clients. Tesla has also cut 14,500 jobs due to slowing demand and stiff competition in China. Meanwhile, Nvidia's CEO Jensen Huang has committed to no job cuts, which may be a key reason why he is highly rated by employees. According to Layoffs.fyi, the top 10 tech companies with the most layoffs in 2024 are: Dell (26,000), Intel (15,000), Tesla (14,500), Cisco (10,150), SAP (8,000), Toshiba (4,000), Paytm (3,500), Getir (3,300), PayPal (2,585), and UKG (2,200).
news knowledge.title: Ranked: The Biggest Layoffs in Tech So Far in 2024

news knowledge.eng_title: A comprehensive list of 2024 tech layoffs | TechCrunch
news knowledge.summary: In 2024, the tech industry has seen significant layoffs across various companies. According to Layoffs.fyi, a total of 60,000 job cuts have been reported across 254 companies. Notable companies that have conducted layoffs include Tesla, Amazon, Google, TikTok, Snap, and Microsoft. Smaller startups have also been affected, with some shutting down operations altogether. The layoffs have resulted in a reduction of 49.9% of Tesla's workforce, 15% of Amazon's workforce, 15% of Google's workforce, 17% of TikTok's workforce, 17% of Snap's workforce, and 10% of Microsoft's workforce. The reasons for the layoffs vary, with some companies citing cost-cutting measures, while others have mentioned a shift in focus towards AI and automation. The layoffs have also led to a significant reduction in the workforce of various startups, with some companies laying off up to 70% of their employees. The impact of the layoffs on the tech industry is still being felt, and it remains to be seen how the industry will recover from this significant reduction in workforce.
news knowledge.title: A comprehensive list of 2024 tech layoffs | TechCrunch

news knowledge.eng_title: More Than 1,30,000 Techies Have Been Laid Off Since Jan 2024 Amid Hiring Freeze And Job Cuts: Report
news knowledge.summary: According to a layoff tracking firm, over 1,30,000 tech industry job cuts have occurred since January 2024, with 397 tech companies affected. The layoffs are attributed to a combination of factors, including the global surge in joblessness and the launch of AI tools by tech giants. Notable layoffs include Cisco's 5% workforce reduction (4000 jobs), Intel's 15% workforce reduction (15000 jobs), Tesla's 10% workforce reduction (14000 jobs), Google's 6% workforce reduction (12000 jobs), and Meta's 13% workforce reduction (11000 jobs). Industry leaders like Narayan Murthy have even advocated for a 70-hour work week, exacerbating the issue. Several companies are taking advantage of the massive joblessness by hiring desperate candidates at below-par packages.
news knowledge.title: More Than 1,30,000 Techies Have Been Laid Off Since Jan 2024 Amid Hiring Freeze And Job Cuts: Report

news knowledge.eng_title: Tesla misses earnings targets for fourth-straight quarter
news knowledge.summary: Tesla has reported its lowest profit margin in over five years, missing its earnings targets for the fourth consecutive quarter. The company has faced slower sales and high costs due to layoffs and AI projects. Despite this, Tesla is on track to deliver new models in the first half of next year, including more affordable vehicles. Shares fell 8% in after-hours trading. CEO Elon Musk has prioritized self-driving robotaxis, which has boosted the company's shares. However, the launch of the robotaxi has been delayed from August to October. Musk attributed the sales slump to new competitors discounting their electric vehicles. Tesla expects an increase in production from July to September and is likely to get approval for its Full Self-Driving software in China and Europe by the end of the year.
news knowledge.title: Tesla misses earnings targets for fourth-straight quarter

news knowledge.eng_title: Tech Layoffs Lose Momentum as AI Takes Center Stage
news knowledge.summary: The wave of tech layoffs has lost momentum. After the horror year 2022, the big tech companies started laying off employees at the beginning of 2023 to signal to investors that CEOs understood the situation. Meta-CEO Mark Zuckerberg was the most aggressive, cutting 22% of the workforce. The stock market applauded, and Meta's stock price rose from $88 to a record high of $542. The rally is not unique to Meta; big tech stocks have seen significant gains over the past year and a half. Layoffs are no longer a major theme to keep investors happy. As a result, the number of layoffs in 2024 has been declining compared to the previous year. According to Layoffs.fyi, there were 60,000 layoffs in the US tech and internet sector from the beginning of the year to early July. Stocklytics reported around 100,000 layoffs worldwide in the tech sector. The largest layoffs occurred at the beginning of the year, with Tesla, SAP, Dell, Cisco, and Toshiba being among the companies that laid off thousands of employees. Microsoft also laid off almost 3,000 employees to establish a sustainable cost structure. The recent layoffs may seem manageable, but the critical question is how artificial intelligence (AI) will impact the workforce. While most big tech companies are investing heavily in AI development, some are already replacing human workers with AI and openly communicating the move. IBM, for example, laid off employees in connection with AI initiatives and plans to replace almost 8,000 jobs with AI. IBM CEO Arvind Krishna stated that the company will 'massively upskill all our employees in AI'. The statement sounded more like a threat than a reassurance.
news knowledge.title: Tech-Kündigungswelle verliert an Schwung

news knowledge.eng_title: Tesla posts new AI, robotics jobs after record layoffs
news knowledge.summary: Tesla has posted over 800 job openings, mostly in robotics and artificial intelligence, after a record number of layoffs earlier this year. The new hires will focus on developing self-driving software for autopilot and robotaxi programs, as well as contribute to the humanoid robotics project Optimus. This shift in focus comes after a successful second-quarter report and a victory for CEO Elon Musk at the annual shareholder meeting, which boosted the company's share price. The renewed hiring focus signals a pivot towards emerging technologies like AI and robotaxis, following a challenging start to 2024.
news knowledge.title: Tesla posts new AI, robotics jobs after record layoffs

news knowledge.eng_title: Tesla Seeks to Fill Ranks After Laying Off Thousands of Workers
news knowledge.summary: Tesla is hiring over 800 workers in the US to fill various positions, including construction, manufacturing, artificial intelligence, and robotics, just three months after laying off thousands of employees worldwide. The company had previously announced a hiring freeze and eliminated thousands of job openings. Elon Musk, CEO, stated that the rapid growth of Tesla led to role duplication and function in some areas. The company is now looking to fill new positions, including 64 jobs related to AI and robotics, and 25 jobs related to autonomous driving technology. Tesla is also developing a fleet of autonomous 'robotaxis' and plans to launch a network that combines Airbnb and Uber. The company has delayed the unveiling of its autonomous driving technology, but plans to showcase it in October.
news knowledge.title: Tesla cherche à remplir ses rangs après qu'Elon Musk ait licencié des milliers de travailleurs

news knowledge.eng_title: Tesla Seeks to Fill Positions After Massive Layoffs
news knowledge.summary: Tesla is hiring over 800 workers in the US to fill positions in various fields, including construction, manufacturing, artificial intelligence, and robotics, just three months after a massive wave of layoffs. The company had previously laid off around 19,600 employees, or about 14%, of its workforce. Tesla's CEO, Elon Musk, has stated that the company's rapid growth has led to a duplication of roles and functions in certain areas. The new job postings have appeared slowly on Tesla's career page over the past few weeks. The company is looking to fill at least 64 positions related to AI and robotics, including the development of its Optimus robots and the Dojo supercomputer. Tesla plans to use Dojo to process the vast amounts of data collected by its electric vehicles. The company is also hiring for positions related to autonomous driving technology and is expected to launch a fleet of autonomous 'robotaxis' in the future. However, Tesla has delayed its planned presentation of its autonomous driving technology and now plans to demonstrate it in October.
news knowledge.title: Tesla busca llenar sus filas después de que Elon Musk despidiera a miles de trabajadores
